headline.main: The Next Public Health Crisis: Longevity

docs.abstract: One of the nation's largest public health schools begins to ponder aging as a national emergency.
docs.lead_paragraph: Since her appointment as dean of the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University in 2008, Dr. Linda P. Fried, a geriatrician, has sought to make the dramatic aging of the world's population, and its myriad ramifications, one of the pillars of education for the 1,100 graduate students there.
docs.snippet: One of the nation's largest public health schools begins to ponder aging as a national emergency.

headline.print_headline: United Nations Report Focuses on Global Lot of Women
headline.main: United Nations Report Focuses on Global Lot of Women

docs.lead_paragraph: Women have made progress in areas like health and education, but they still lag over all, according to the U.N. report, World’s Women 2010.
docs.snippet: Women have made progress in areas like health and education, but they still lag over all, according to the U.N. report, World’s Women 2010.

docs.abstract: An ad promoting breast feeding looks a lot like an ad for NutriSystem.
docs.lead_paragraph: October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and studies show one way to reduce your risk of the disease is to breastfeed. There is also evidence that breastfeeding increases a child's IQ, while boosting her immune system and lowering her lifetime risk of obesity.
docs.snippet: An ad promoting breast feeding looks a lot like an ad for NutriSystem.

headline.seo: TED Prize Goes to J R, Who Gives Slums a Human Face
headline.print_headline: Award to Artist Who Gives Slums a Human Face
headline.main: Award to Artist Who Gives Slums a Human Face

docs.lead_paragraph: The TED prize for 2011 will go to J R, who plasters colossal photos in downtrodden neighborhoods around the world.
docs.snippet: The TED prize for 2011 will go to J R, who plasters colossal photos in downtrodden neighborhoods around the world.

headline.main: The Pedometer Test: Americans Take Fewer Steps

docs.abstract: Americans are thousands of steps behind other countries when it comes to daily physical activity, according to new research that used pedometers to measure movement.
docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are thousands of steps behind other countries when it comes to daily physical activity, according to new research that used pedometers to measure movement.
docs.snippet: Americans are thousands of steps behind other countries when it comes to daily physical activity, according to new research that used pedometers to measure movement.

headline.main: Going on a Diet? Start Paying in Cash

docs.abstract: Paying with credit or debit cards makes people more likely to make impulsive food purchases, according to a new study.
docs.lead_paragraph: Paying with credit or debit cards makes people more likely to make impulsive, unhealthy food purchases, according to a new study in The Journal of Consumer Research.
docs.snippet: Paying with credit or debit cards makes people more likely to make impulsive food purchases, according to a new study.

docs.abstract: An article in the most recent issue of Brain, Child magazine argues that by the time today's toddlers turn 18, the book-based world for which college prepares you will be an obsolete relic.
docs.lead_paragraph: There are many reasons not to start the push toward college before your child is even in preschool. You know most of them, but here's one you might not have thought of: There is no point in pushing children, because by the time today's toddlers turn 18, college -- along with the book-based world for which college prepares you -- will be an obsolete relic.
docs.snippet: An article in the most recent issue of Brain, Child magazine argues that by the time today's toddlers turn 18, the book-based world for which college prepares you will be an obsolete relic.

headline.seo: Longevity of Hispanics Is Analyzed in Study
headline.print_headline: AGING: Charting a ‘Hispanic Paradox’ in Longevity
headline.main: Aging: Longer Life Expectancy Seen for Hispanics

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite high rates of poverty, obesity and diabetes and relatively low rates of health insurance, Hispanics in the United States tend to outlive African-Americans and non-Hispanic whites.
docs.snippet: Despite high rates of poverty, obesity and diabetes and relatively low rates of health insurance, Hispanics in the United States tend to outlive African-Americans and non-Hispanic whites.

headline.main: Unlikely Allies in Food Stamp Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: In the debate over whether the poor can buy soft drinks with food stamps, antihunger advocates are teamed up with Big Food and Big Beverage.
docs.snippet: In the debate over whether the poor can buy soft drinks with food stamps, antihunger advocates are teamed up with Big Food and Big Beverage.
